title: Ethnic Restaurants
name: Ethnic Restaurants
description:
A Map by Baostar

Authentic ethnic restaurants in Orange County, CA.

properties.name: Al Amir Bakery
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 518 S Brookhurst #3, Anaheim, CA 92804-2447From OC Weekly: Al Amir Bakery in Anaheim’s Little Arabia enclave attracts all sorts of eaters, but it works best as an old-style pizzeria, a place where young people step in for a quick bite and flirt. And you get them all—and more—here: Arab B-boys in white hats and untucked long-sleeved shirts crunking Usher from their Lincoln Navigators; little boys and girls darting around their hijab-bedecked mommy, fighting over the last drops of dough, the Middle Eastern yogurt drink; students poring over textbooks, waiting for their study buddy; men in suits stopping in for a snack before walking across the way to smoke at one of the shopping plaza’s two hookah lounges. There’s not much yet in the way of lean-to counters and jukeboxes, but it’s no big deal: Al Amir’s primary draw is its extraordinary sphihas, what clueless food critics—me—describe as Lebanese pizza. In my defense, sphihas appear like New York-style pies, thanks to their thin, toasty, wonderfully crunchy crust. And the preparation is identical: cooks roll flat a ball of pita-bread flour in the backroom kitchen, layer it with the ingredients of your choice, and then shove the proto-sphiha into the small brick oven near the cash register. It’s ready in about four minutes. Sphihas are about all Al Amir produces—no baklava, no hummus, no grape leaves and just one type of sandwich stuffed with lettuce, tomatoes, charred beef and nutty tahini sauce. Unlike so many pizzas, though, the flavors in these sphihas are intense and quite rare—this is only the second sphiha shop in the county after the esteemed Al-Sanabel Bakery. The cheese is Akawi, a slightly tough Palestinian strain that confuses at first with a salty coating but eventually reveals a luscious, sweet milk flavor inside your mouth. You can eat an all-Akawi sphiha, but it’s best when combined with meats—say, soujouk, the spicy beef sausage that’s the pepperoni of the Middle East, or the tart minced-meat spread lahmbaajin. Vegetarians can relish a sphiha sprinkled with zaatar, a zesty pesto of thyme with olive oil and sesame seeds that will pucker your palate. And there are more sphihas—seven in total. They’re the size of an individual pizza, yet impossibly cheap—the most expensive tops out at .50, while a fresh spinach sphiha is an obscene 99 cents. No sales tax!

properties.name: Al Sanabel Bakery
properties.description: Posted by Baostar816 S. Brookhurst Blvd., Anaheim, CAWhile Bolsa Ave in Westminster is known as "Little Saigon", and Garden Grove Blvd in Garden Grove, "Little Seoul" for their Vietnamese and Korean food and culture respectively, Brookhurst Blvd in Anaheim is becoming informally known as "Little Gaza" for its Middle Eastern fare. Al Sanabel Bakery is located this area, dense with Arabic restaurants, bakeries and markets. The specialty of the house is a flat-bread pizza topped with a heady layer of pounded thyme or ground beef, the Lebanese sausage known as soujok, or parsley and mint-flecked white cheese. They\'re all around -. The kefteh kebab - a remarkably juicy strip of ground beef surrounded by tangy sumac-marinated onions and rolled in pita.

properties.name: Au Lac
properties.description: Posted by Baobot16563 Brookhurst St, Fountain Valley, CAVegetarian- and vegan-friendly restaurant serving Vietnamese and Chinese cuisine. Meals have soy-based meats and are used to create authentic dishes without the use of meat, eggs or alcohol.

properties.name: Beba's Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Mbuzi 630 South Grand Avenue Suite 102, Santa Ana, CA, 92705Bolivian. OC Weekly\'s Best Holes-in-the-Wall.

properties.name: Brodard Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  9892 Westminster Ave., Suite R, Garden Grove, CA 92844 Vietnamese restaurant known for its spring rolls, freshly made by an assembly line of women in open view of diners. The lines at the takeout counter prove that everyone in Little Saigon knows Brodard is the place for spring rolls, perhaps best described to gringos as salad rolls of meat, lettuce, mint, cucumber and other fresh veggies wrapped in translucent rice paper. Brodard makes five kinds of the fresh rolls: You can get the standard, ubiquitous fresh shrimp and sliced pork version here, but the house specialties are more worth your time -- the Nem Nuong Cuon, featuring nem, sweet grilled Vietnamese sausage (referred to as a pork cake or paste) and a crispy fried leek, and the Chao Tom Cuon, with a grilled shrimp cake ("paste") rather than fresh shrimp. An order of 3 hearty rolls runs about .75. Also recommended: The roasted duck salad (.95), numerous versions of bun (another salad-like dish of rice noodles, lettuce and carrots topped with meat or seafood and tangy sauce), and banh xeo, a pan-fried crispy rice-flour crepe flavored with coconut milk and stuffed with shrimp, sliced pork and bean sprouts (.25).

properties.name: Byblos Café
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  129 W. Chapman Ave., Orange, CAPale lemon-colored walls of a magnificent height set off large Picasso-style paintings by a young artist/waitress. The windows are neatly trimmed in white and deep green. The back patio is a jungle of plants and umbrellas, with colored lights after dark. Byblos Cafe hosts a satisfying combination of the fierce and the refined. Try feta cheese omelettes at breakfast, a giant Greek salad with shrimp for lunch, Lebanese wine with shaworma for dinner.

properties.name: Christaki's Greek Cuisine
properties.description: Posted by System13011 Newport Ave Ste 113, Tustin, CAChristaki\'s Greek Cuisine (714) 731-1179

properties.name: El Pollo de Oro
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 101 W. Fourth St., Santa Ana, CAEl Pollo de Oro specializes in grilled chicken along with other traditional Mexican favorites. You can get chicken in many other forms here, such as taquitos, the tacos, burritos, etc. Carnitas and carne asada are also served. You can order a big pile of nachos, heaping with anything you can think of with cheese. A fruit stand is almost always set up on the sidewalk where you can get sweet mango sprinkled with chili powder if your mouth hasn\'t been adequately tinged from El Pollo\'s brick-red salsa.

properties.name: Gabbi's Mexican Kitchen
properties.description: Posted by Baobot141 S. Glassell St., Orange, CA, United StatesSeating is either inside in a dark, deep, narrow dining room or on a small patio that sits along Glassell. If the weather is comfortable, hope for an outside table, especially if you catch it at that time of day when the sun is wilting away and the first moments of evening arrive with an embracing breeze. There may not be a better table in the county at that moment. Particularly if you have before you Panuchos de Yucatan, essentially three sliders of perfect chunks of pork on tortillas, an icy margarita and ceviche, a bowl of unrestrained flavor, full of tart citrus, sweet mango, bite of fish, red onion and cilantro. If you forgo the margarita, do not deny yourself the horchata here. It\'s sweet, creamy and full of cinnamon. Be warned, they do run out. (Reviewed in The Orange County Register Sept. 21, 2006, by Tenny Tatusian).

properties.name: India Cook House
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 14130 Culver Dr., Irvine, CA, 92620Recommended: The garlic naan, and roti and mango lassi drink.

properties.name: Kassra
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 27261 La Paz Road, Laguna Niguel, CAPersians have a wonderful potato chicken salad that\'s mayonnaise-based and yet not heavy. Kassra makes a very good version of it, chunky with white-meat chicken and diced potatoes. For , it\'s a perfect meal.

properties.name: Kitayama
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 101 Bayview Place, Newport Beach, CA, 92660Kitayama continues to meet a standard of beauty that transcends trends. Booths have flowing dove-gray curtains and plum-colored cushions. The blond wood and woven hanging lights add warmth without heaviness. The sushi, shabu shabu and green-tea ice cream are recommended. Wine pick is Izumi Judan sake.

properties.name: Long Hai
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 682 El Camino Real, Tustin, CAVery good banh hoi - thin rice noodles woven into pancakes, lettuce, mint, cilantro, fish sauce, peanuts and a choice of meat (barbecued pork, shrimp, etc).

properties.name: Mangga Grill
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 341 E 1st St , Tustin, CA714-730-1332

properties.name: Mas' Islamic Chinese
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 601 E. Orangethorpe Ave., AnaheimAt the very, very center of Islamic Chinese food is a round of sesame-flecked bread, a minor flour-and-water achievement that\'s as thick as the Bibles smuggled into China, with three or four doughy strata hovering between crispy top and bottom planks. The bread, which must share DNA with ancient oven-baked Middle Eastern breads, is fine on its own, but even better when it replaces rice to soak up sauce from the shredded chicken with dry bean curd or to dunk into a warm pot of lamb stew. At Mas\' Islamic Chinese restaurant in Anaheim, you\'ll have to wait at least 15 minutes for an order of it, but that\'s fine; it\'s the sort of food that shouldn\'t be made ahead of time. You can have it stuffed with green onions, or not. There\'s also a sweet version filled with red bean paste. The restaurant stands in an industrial section near Fullerton, and with its indoor fountain, large chandelier hanging inside a domed ceiling, red walls and the presence of owner Jamilla Ma in white headdress, it feels as though it dropped down from the sky. Ma owned the other Islamic Chinese restaurant in Orange County, Jamillah Garden in Tustin, which she sold two years ago. The menu is essentially the same. Plenty of familiar Chinese dishes, all prepared in the Halal way, according to Muslim dietary rules. Pork and alcohol are verboten ingredients. There\'s a stronger-than-usual emphasis on lamb and tripe. She serves handmade, nicely chewy noodles. And of course, there\'s the bread, which doesn\'t appear too much in Islamic restaurants in China where it\'s so commonplace in homes no one orders it outside. Other than that, though, the menu is very familiar to anybody who\'s ever ordered an egg roll, a pot sticker or kung pao anything. There\'s a very nice shredded chicken with dry bean curd that\'s at once mildly sweet and spicy. The hot-braised shrimp is forgettable, but the salt-and-pepper shrimp is worth fighting over, each little pink curl crispy from a coating of its two seasonings and a toss into a sizzling hot pan. I was underwhelmed by the steamed dumplings and pot stickers (even though the dough draping both was pleasantly toothsome) and the fried calamari, which looked like onion rings, was unremarkable even if its crust was as crispy as it gets. But the sautéed pea-pod leaves, while tasting very familiar, seemed refreshing: bright green leaves still attached to crispy stalks, flecked with garlic and glistening with a touch of sesame oil. The dry sautéed string beans were crunchy and nicely charred in spots and the eggplant with curry, practically a savory pudding, was very good. The homemade noodles show up in both brothy dishes and chow meins. They\'re irregular cuts, thick and chewy in spots, more tender at different points along the strands. The lamb stew warm pot is a bracing dish, the broth tinged with anise and other ingredients in Chinese five-spice powder. Big chunks of supremely tender lamb still on the bone float about, although you must negotiate the clinging bits of white fat. Most beef dishes are worth your time. The stir-fry leek with beef is brazen in its embrace of five-spice powder, the beef deeply red, fully cooked and supple. Mas\' is the place where you want to start with the familiar and then tiptoe over to the cold spicy beef, the cold spicy tripe and the ox tongue in brown sauce. One day, the cold jellyfish might be a weekly necessity. -ocregister

properties.name: Mil Jugos
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 318 W 5th St, Santa AnaA tiny Venezuelan restaurant in downtown Santa Ana on Fifth Street between Ross and Broadway. The name translates into 1,000 juices, but in reality, you have a choice of about 20 fruit juices. Yet the juices aren\'t really the story here. Go for the arepas or cachapas. The arepas look like whoopi pies: round pale corn cake domes stuffed with shredded beef or chicken or thick slices of tender, wine-marinated eye-of-round steak. The cachapas are thick folded sweet pancakes stuffed with the same, except my favorite is a simple filling of cheese and cream. The tres leches cake is ethereal, rich and spiced with cinnamon.

properties.name: Nguyen Thuy Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 9372 Westminster Ave., Westminster, CAThe Banh Hoi is delicious here. It\'s served on a large, bamboo tray with an assortment of grilled pork, meatballs and sugar cane prawn, along with delicate vermicelli topped with sautéed green onions, fresh green-leaf lettuce, mint and slices of cucumber, and nuoc mam, or dipping sauce, on the side.

properties.name: Nory's Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by System 23798 Mercury Rd, Lake Forest, CANory\'s Restaurant (949) 458-0318

properties.name: Osaka Kappo
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 13681 Newport Ave., Tustin, CA, 92780Tucked in an expansive strip mall, this Japanese restaurant offers top-notch food without the high prices. "Kappo" refers to an a la carte style of meal service, which is representative of the dinner service. The special of the day is always worth trying, typically a combination meal pairing a homestyle favorite like broiled fish with a bowl of soba or udon noodles and rounded out with rice, miso soup and salad. The sashimi and sushi here are also high quality; order the sashimi plate and the chef presents a colorful array of the delicate raw slices, garnished with shiso leaf and radish shredded and cut into artful display.

properties.name: Papa Hassan's
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 421 S. Glassell St., Orange, CAA favorite of students, professors and local business folk since 1977. Brothers Mahmoud Haidar and Mustafa Hassan continue to sling out creamy hummus, fluffy rice, juicy kabobs and comforting casseroles at astonishing prices. Daily specials range from to and include soup or salad. Or you can order a sandwich - spicy potato or shawarma, for instance - for tops. If you find yourself with a little extra cash, don\'t think twice about ordering a beguiling dessert of sweet pudding on a thin layer of drenched bread tasting of milk and honey they call, appropriately enough, "heaven."

properties.name: Pho Kimmy
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 14932 Bushard St., Westminster, CA 92683The broth for the beef pho has been cooked so long that it\'s a deep brown. Fresh meat toppings. There are always lines out the door.

properties.name: Sahara Falafel
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 590 S Brookhurst St, Anaheim, CA 92804Sahara Falafel is at the very tip of an area known to some as Little Gaza. This part of Brookhurst and its cross streets is the spot for dozens of Middle Eastern businesses, where frequent Arabic signs and their English translations advertise falafel, kebabs, shawarma, meats and pastries. If you\'re hungry, this is Mecca.

properties.name: Seoul Garden BBQ Buffet
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 13828 Red Hill Ave, Tustin, CAClean, good service and many types of fresh meat at this all-you-can-eat barbecue restaurant.

properties.name: Seoul Oak
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 8295 Garden Grove Blvd., Garden Grove, CASeoul Oak offers a wide variety of side dishes you don\'t get anywhere else, like candied lotus root, and various types of kim chee, like one with oyster marinade. Order the crab.

properties.name: Shik Do Rak
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 9691 Garden Grove Blvd., Garden Grove, CA 92844The specialty here is duk bo sam, a type of barbecue where you grill your own meat and vegetables and wrap them in rice paper.

properties.name: Sitar Authentic Indian Cuisine
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 1401 S. Harbor Blvd., Fullerton, CARecommended: Two types of butter chicken dishes called murgh tikka masala and murgh makhani. For dessert, try a rice pudding called kheer and a dough soaked in syrup called gulab jamoon.

properties.name: Thai Nakorn
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 11951 Beach Blvd., Stanton, CANew location - opening soon.

properties.name: Tropika
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 17460 E. 17th St., Tustin, CAThe first Maylasian restaurant to open in Orange County. Update: my neighbors and I finally went to Tropika last month and enjoyed the food immensely. We had the Pangan Seabass with minced shallots, red chili & lemon sauce wrapped in banana leaf (2 for whole fish), Roti Prata (crispy Indian style bread served with curry sauce), Mango Salad, Pineapple Curry Prawns, Potato Curry Chicken, Malay Sizzling Beef, Malay Peanut Crepe (crispy pancake stuffed with ground peanuts), and Mango and Coconut Puddings. Desserts were on the house - thanks to Daniel, owner of the restaurant and also our neighbor. We couldn\'t get enough of the Pangan Seabass and Roti Prata - highly recommended!

properties.name: Village Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  22902 Los Alisos Blvd. #G, Mission Viejo, CA 92691 Serves Middle Eastern food and has excellent shwarama and baklava.

properties.name: Zankou Chicken
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 2424 W. Ball Road, Anaheim, CAIt\'s probably the best rotisserie chicken you\'ll ever find - the color of 24-carat gold, with crispy skin and tender meat. It comes with a pungent garlic paste that you\'ll taste for hours, if not days, afterward. Or try the great shawarma - both beef and chicken.
